- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/634666/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 46m 25s'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-02-04 14:06:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-02-04 14:06:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-02-04 15:42:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/634666/2 : SUCCESS in 1h 35m 43s'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-02-05 07:25:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Workflow

ready for reviews'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-02-07 12:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I don't understand why do you consider the agent is restarted in the second state report. "_report_state" will be called periodically depending on the "agent_conf.report_interval". But how can you ensure the agent is already restarted (according the the bug description) just by waiting one reporting cycle? If the system is too loaded (too many ports), just by delaying one cycle the started flag won't solve the problem reported in the bug.

Although the solution I proposed in [1] is not finished, at least IMO the idea is correct: once the first agent loop is finished, we can consider the agent is fully restarted.

BTW, maybe adding this new parameter I suggest in [1] is unnecessary, but at least the idea of waiting till the end of the first loop should be the way we should handle this.


[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615246'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-02-08 08:50:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

>>I don't understand why do you consider the agent is restarted in the second state report. "_report_state" will be called periodically depending on the "agent_conf.report_interval". But how can you ensure the agent is already restarted (according the the bug description) just by waiting one reporting cycle? If the system is too loaded (too many ports), just by delaying one cycle the started flag won't solve the problem reported in the bug.

It’s not about second state_report loop, but second rpc_loop. "if self.iter_num > 0” effectively means that agent has synced all ports with server.

>>Although the solution I proposed in [1] is not finished, at least IMO the idea is correct: once the first agent loop is finished, we can consider the agent is fully restarted.

>>BTW, maybe adding this new parameter I suggest in [1] is unnecessary, but at least the idea of waiting till the end of the first loop should be the way we should handle this.

agree, and that’s what this patch is doing: sending start_flag always while ports are not processed (during iter 0).'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-02-12 09:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Rodolfo did you have a chance to check my answers? should I maybe clarify more on the approach?'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-02-13 16:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> @Rodolfo did you have a chance to check my answers? should I maybe
 > clarify more on the approach?

I would prefer someone else to comment on this patch. But IMO, if the problem is to identify when the agent has executed at least a first loop (on start and restart), we should detect when this agent loop has finished. With this patch, if the first agent loop takes more than the "agent_boot_time", we'll still have this problem.

Also if we identify how to detect correctly when the agent has at least finished a first loop (as I said, on start and restart), we'll be able to speed up, in light loaded systems, the boot up time.'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-03-04 07:00:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

>>With this patch, if the first agent loop takes more than the "agent_boot_time", we'll still have this problem.

If look into get_agent_uptime() method (used for identifying if agent was restarted) we can see that it takes delta of agent.started_at and last agent.heartbeat_timestamp - so if we send start flag in each report while agent is processing first rpc loop, this delta will always be less than agent_boot_time and hence we’re good.

>>Also if we identify how to detect correctly when the agent has at least finished a first loop (as I said, on start and restart), we'll be able to speed up, in light loaded systems, the boot up time.

agree, ideally we should get rid of this agent_boot_time at all and agent should request the full list when needed. The idea of current patch however is to make it as simple a possible, and more importantly backportable (to Pike at least).

This is a very painful problem on large clusters which obviously cannot be easily upgraded to latest OSt version.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-03-04 11:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

1) You are right: while in loop=0 (first loop still ongoing), we are sending the start_flag every time we report the state. So I have another question: is OK to fake the starting time every time we report the state in the first loop?

2) You agree with me on the idea of reporting better when the first loop is done. Thanks!
I also agree with you on the idea of making this as simple as possible to be able to cherry-pick it to previous versions.

This implementation works but I would prefer something more elaborated (actually could be something easy to implement) to determine when the first loop is over and the agent could be considered as "started", instead of pushing forward (faking) the agent start time.

I would +1 it but with a technical debt to be solved.'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-03-04 11:40:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Rodolfo, thanks. I'm also not quite happy with faking start time, but I failed to find any other way without the need to modify RPC interface. 
Also I was thinking of which logic may be broken with this kind of faking (some scripts relying on agent reported start time.. what would they do?) and nothing came to my mind."}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-03-04 12:39:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In systems that are heavily loaded or congested, do we run the risk of systemd restarting a service or considering the start as failed because ovs-neutron-agent did not signal that it is ready within the time limit due to a very slow sync?'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-03-04 13:01:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Nate I don't think systemd (or anything else) does consider agent as started based on start_flag absence in state report of the agent which is the only way how this patch may affect this."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-04-04 08:26:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2019-04-05 00:44:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 7016, 'date': '2019-04-05 17:52:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/stein as commit 382431c944e21ef6aab06f3746f23a84f7425cb2'}]

commit_message:
OVS agent: always send start flag during initial sync

In order to avoid inaccurate agent_boot_time setting,
this patch suggests to consider agent as "started" only
after completion of initial sync with server.

Change-Id: Icba05288889219e8a606c3809efd88b2c234bef3
Closes-Bug: #1799178

and tests, and that the current dev release is enabled
in metadata.  Dev release tests are enabled separately
because of chickens and eggs.

commit_message:
Check Volume Status on attachment create/update

Currently the new Attachment calls in Cinder aren't checking the status
of the volume when create or update is called.  This isn't good because
it can mask problems with attach processes on the volume.

This patch adds an explicit check of the volume status in both
attachment_create and attachment_update, and if the volume status is in
any error state, the call will result in an InvalidVolume exception.

This is an API change to fix a bug, and is not microversioned.

Closes-Bug: #1805762

Change-Id: I9b32c4db93879dda6490b244643de1a18bddbbf5
(cherry picked from commit 7d7dc2659d1ad07ef77892306827ca4a662e315d)
(cherry picked from commit b9a9492baca004494dd099e2e2d0180cc8483b28)

Do you have some profiling results you could share? I'm interested in what effect expanding the default for of_request_timeout has. I agree that at scale looping around to a full-sync just keeps the system in a death-spiral, but I'm nervous about the side-effects of waiting longer for openflow requests to time out."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-02-23 12:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-02-23 12:22:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Do you have some profiling results you could share? I'm interested
 > in what effect expanding the default for of_request_timeout has. I
 > agree that at scale looping around to a full-sync just keeps the
 > system in a death-spiral, but I'm nervous about the side-effects of
 > waiting longer for openflow requests to time out.

I've tested these serial of patches in such way:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/745685/
But if of_connect_timeout and of_request_timeout stay the default value, I can still meet those timeout exception. It's probability is about 50%. So I have to increase these value until I meet a 90% restart success rate. Yes, I'm not quite sure about the side-effects of these, let's wait and see more feedbacks."}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-02-23 13:45:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I'm not sure if changing default values is good idea. It is config option so if some user got heavy loaded environment, he can always increase those values.
If those new values can be really better and more "universal", maybe we can hardcode those values and get rid of config options? If it has no side effects like You said, what's the point to keep those values configurable?'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-03-25 10:15:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> I'm not sure if changing default values is good idea. It is config
 > option so if some user got heavy loaded environment, he can always
 > increase those values.

Correct, operators can increase the values. This patch has no conflicts with that.

 > If those new values can be really better and more "universal",
 > maybe we can hardcode those values and get rid of config options?

We are trying to give users a more proper default value of this config. For my experiences, lots of user do not set this config in their environment, or use the default value. When their cloud meets the scale issue, they always need to re-config the options. The new default value can save their time.

 > If it has no side effects like You said, what's the point to keep
 > those values configurable?

This should be answered by the original author who added these options. : ) But, IMO, an option is sometimes simple for implemention. Meanwhile hard code is not so much robust.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-27 09:11:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: -Code-Review

> > I'm not sure if changing default values is good idea. It is
 > config
 > > option so if some user got heavy loaded environment, he can
 > always
 > > increase those values.
 > 
 > Correct, operators can increase the values. This patch has no
 > conflicts with that.
 > 
 > > If those new values can be really better and more "universal",
 > > maybe we can hardcode those values and get rid of config options?
 > 
 > We are trying to give users a more proper default value of this
 > config. For my experiences, lots of user do not set this config in
 > their environment, or use the default value. When their cloud meets
 > the scale issue, they always need to re-config the options. The new
 > default value can save their time.
 > 
 > > If it has no side effects like You said, what's the point to keep
 > > those values configurable?
 > 
 > This should be answered by the original author who added these
 > options. : ) But, IMO, an option is sometimes simple for
 > implemention. Meanwhile hard code is not so much robust.

IMHO this approach is bit odd because what You are doing here is something like "we have config option which (probably) nobody uses so lets change default value of it to tune it up for users". If there is no any side effects of using high value for it, and nobody is tuning it, why not hardcode it? Or maybe we should do this change but also document this option better? Explain what can be side effects of increasing/decreasing its values, when user should tune it and what can expect when they will set lower/higher values for it.

I will remove my -1 from it to not "block" this change.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-03-27 12:12:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-03-27 12:13:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-03-27 18:02:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

commit_message:
Change default local ovs connection timeout

Large number of flows can cause local ovs connection
timeout. Ultimately getting succeed will be better
than a retry or fullsync.

Related-Bug: #1813703
Related-Bug: #1813705
Related-Bug: #1813707
Related-Bug: #1813709

Change-Id: Ifa0608a7e131df3cad2f7727426720afce641a58

Blair', 'email': 'jim@acmegating.com', 'username': 'corvus'}, {'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 970, 'name': 'Dean Troyer', 'email': 'dtroyer@gmail.com', 'username': 'dtroyer'}, {'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5263, 'name': 'Jeremy Stanley', 'display_name': 'fungi', 'email': 'fungi@yuggoth.org', 'username': 'fungi', 'status': 'missing, presumed fed'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10343, 'name': 'Jim Rollenhagen', 'email': 'jim@jimrollenhagen.com', 'username': 'jimrollenhagen'}, {'_account_id': 10607, 'name': 'Alexandra Settle', 'email': 'a.settle@outlook.com', 'username': 'asettle'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

[{'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-22 14:24:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-22 14:25:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-22 14:28:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-03-22 14:36:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-22 14:38:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-22 14:48:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-22 14:59:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Still reviewing, but looks like you'll want to add a 2019 section to doc/source/resolutions/index.rst so the openstack-tox-docs job will pass."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-03-22 15:11:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-22 15:20:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-03-24 17:21:34.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from repository-namespaces to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-03-24 19:27:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I feel like we should at least get to reserve the namespaces linked to our project names for projects to use, i.e. nova/nova.

I'm not sure how that translates into mirroring things on GitHub, however."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-03-25 02:30:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-25 11:42:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-25 12:41:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-25 13:03:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-03-26 16:14:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@mnaser has a good point re namespaces that are also project names.  Maybe that should be handled at a policy level for OpenDev?  Only allow namespaces to duplicate project names when that project is actually using that namespace?  ie, nova/nova is fine but nova/openstackclient would not be allowed, for an extreme example'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-26 16:30:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Perhaps I'm just not imaginative enough, but I don't see how that would work. Is that something the OpenDev reviewers do special for OpenStack or is it the case for any project which wants to "reserve" a namespace without having any repositories using it? Keep in mind that "namespaces" aren't particularly a separate resource in our systems, merely an emergent property of the naming conventions for our Git repositories. Gitea does have "organizations" which correspond to our notion of namespaces in Gerrit (and we create those automatically when they're referenced as a part of any new Git repository), so I *can* imagine potential implementations for this reservation system... it's more the policies around them which I think would need to be fleshed out if it's something we think OpenDev should consider supporting.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-26 17:54:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Keep it simple, put everything under a common governance ("openstack") under the same namespace (openstack/). Move things that are not under the same governance somewhere else, and into "unknown" if nobody responds.

Reserving $project-team-names/ so that nobody else can namesquat those is a red herring imho. I'd rather have a remediation process where trademark owners can appeal to OpenDev admins to expel squatters, than enter a complex pre-creation vetting process and maintain lists of reserved names.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-26 19:27:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-26 19:28:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-26 19:33:30.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from repository-namespaces to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-27 10:55:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-27 12:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I'm not keen on "unknown" but I don't have a better suggestion to offer.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-27 13:02:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Can we push this through as a project, but change the title of "unknown" later if we get a good suggestion?'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-27 14:28:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Alex - it's a bit fuzzy whether the naming of that "non-openstack" thing should belong to the OpenStack TC anyway. I personally consider "unknown" to be a suggestion, that OpenDev council should be free to override if they come up with a better name for it :)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-27 15:03:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yes, basically what Thierry said... the OpenStack TC has no real jurisdiction to decide what namespace(s) will be used by projects it does not govern, it only gets to say that they can't use its chosen official namespace(s). If the OpenDev sysadmins settle on a preferred alternative catch-all namespace then that's what will be used (though I'm not really able to come up with a better one myself at the moment so also entirely possible the TC's suggestion is "good enough").'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-03-27 15:07:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

lgtm. marking 'unknown' is good trigger/alert I think."}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-27 16:35:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I'm happy to update this resolution to replace "unknown" if OpenDev has something else to suggest. :)'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-28 10:37:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> @Alex - it's a bit fuzzy whether the naming of that "non-openstack"
 > thing should belong to the OpenStack TC anyway. I personally
 > consider "unknown" to be a suggestion, that OpenDev council should
 > be free to override if they come up with a better name for it :)

Perfect then :)'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-03-28 13:15:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-04-05 14:20:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Seems necessary, although I worry how breaking this is going to be for everyone. :('}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-05 14:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-05 14:23:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Seems necessary, although I worry how breaking this is going to be
 > for everyone. :(

It's gonna be breaking for at least a project I know. I was not strongly in favor or against it, so let's just merge it and we move on, to be able to deal with the next steps."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-04-05 14:25:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Breaking in what way(s)? It would be good to enumerate the anticipated pain points so we can work out how they might be more effectively addressed (whether before the transition or shortly after).'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-04-05 16:14:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

For clarity, if the concern is about new locations for projects, redirects will be in place. If there are other concerns I would very much like to hear about them. :)'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-05 17:04:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-05 17:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add resolution to namespace unofficial projects

This resolution wraps up the discussion from [0] and defines a plan.

It's important to note that the OpenDev team is targeting the migration
by April 19[1], so we should merge this resolution and provide a list of
unofficial projects to be moved before that date.

[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003943.html
[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/004056.html

Change-Id: Ib9eb81611d74c93e4b1874a946380aa5b1595d1a

commit_message:
[Queen Only] Add force option to undercloud update.

When the overcloud is in a failed state we can't run the undercloud
upgrade command anymore. But we may need to inject code in mistral for
instance to get out of the overcloud failure.

The force option enables the user to get out of this loop.

Queen only as instack undercloud is removed from Rocky on.

Change-Id: I9e7fe8cfd96262938d463de0d6c45ccedc9989be
Closes-Bug: #1806683
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/622290

subject: Fix rally nova gate job
messages: [{'account_id': 29466, 'date': '2019-04-05 13:56:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-04-05 15:38:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-05 13:56:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix rally nova gate job

It looks like the failure is because nova recently changed policy
to prevent anything except volume-backed instances having zero
size. This commit sets the disk size to 1 as a test.

Change-Id: Idc38260d5ecdca83f12e4619a120a1abc982e394
'}]
commit_message:
Fix rally nova gate job

It looks like the failure is because nova recently changed policy
to prevent anything except volume-backed instances having zero
size. This commit sets the disk size to 1 as a test.

Change-Id: Idc38260d5ecdca83f12e4619a120a1abc982e394

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-04 08:32:03.000000000', 'message': 'SSYNC: Remove reverted objects as soon as possible

This patch enables the SSYNC receiver to returns the list of objects
hash with their status. If all revert jobs of a given (object, timestamps)
are succesful, it can be deleted from disk (in case of a revert job)

TODO: version of ssync for upgrade support
 => might be not needed, need to think more of it

Change-Id: Ic0a80027644d46ba285dc40e65e894e2b0f6463c
'}]
commit_message:
SSYNC: Remove reverted objects as soon as possible

This patch enables the SSYNC receiver to returns the list of objects
hash with their status. If all revert jobs of a given (object, timestamps)
are succesful, it can be deleted from disk (in case of a revert job)

TODO: version of ssync for upgrade support
 => might be not needed, need to think more of it

Change-Id: Ic0a80027644d46ba285dc40e65e894e2b0f6463c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-04 16:40:46.000000000', 'message': "Add a request_timeout to neutron

Neutron's pre-commit processing can take some time
and even exceed 30 seconds in CI. Lets make it 45 and
have an explicit timeout passed for the request handling
to be setup with the python-neutronclient initialization.

Change-Id: I9947656c959af2128e7dbf30ba6b38cc2af35dae
Story: 2005371
Task: 30347
"}]
commit_message:
Add a request_timeout to neutron

Neutron's pre-commit processing can take some time
and even exceed 30 seconds in CI. Lets make it 45 and
have an explicit timeout passed for the request handling
to be setup with the python-neutronclient initialization.

Change-Id: I9947656c959af2128e7dbf30ba6b38cc2af35dae
Story: 2005371
Task: 30347

commit_message:
Add python3 testing

This ensures some python3 testing is done in our gating.
Leap 15 will mostly be python3 only, so it makes sense to test
python3 with Leap15.

Change-Id: I40661f49a13f60c91f6ac73479e4aa3927ec4f58

subject: Specify internal network to improve stability in a multi-NIC scenario.
messages:
[{'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-03-30 08:01:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-04-02 20:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2019-04-02 21:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8064, 'date': '2019-04-02 21:33:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-04-02 21:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2019-04-04 11:21:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think we should revert this if want to have cinder working and go to v1.14.0.

The in-tree cinder plugin breaks with this param.

Another option is to diverge the occm cloud-config file and the in-tree cinder volume-plugin

in kube-controller-manager I get:
Apr 04 11:19:45 kube-calico-occm-1-14-bkium3r55orl-master-0.novalocal runc[3491]: F0404 11:19:45.892495       1 controllermanager.go:213] error building controller context: cloud provider could not be initialized: could not init cloud provider "openstack": warnings:
Apr 04 11:19:45 kube-calico-occm-1-14-bkium3r55orl-master-0.novalocal runc[3491]: can't store data at section "Networking"



If I remove: --external-cloud-volume-plugin=openstack --cloud-config=/etc/kubernetes/cloud-config

diff --git a/magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/configure-kubernetes-master.sh b/magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/configure-kubernetes-master.sh
index e105f57..39ae26b 100644
--- a/magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/configure-kubernetes-master.sh
+++ b/magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/configure-kubernetes-master.sh
@@ -146,7 +146,7 @@ fi
 
 if [ -n "$TRUST_ID" ] && [ "$(echo "${CLOUD_PROVIDER_ENABLED}" | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')" = "true" ]; then
     KUBE_CONTROLLER_MANAGER_ARGS="$KUBE_CONTROLLER_MANAGER_ARGS --cloud-provider=external"
-    KUBE_CONTROLLER_MANAGER_ARGS="$KUBE_CONTROLLER_MANAGER_ARGS --external-cloud-volume-plugin=openstack --cloud-config=/etc/kubernetes/cloud-config"
 fi
 
 

I get
Apr 04 11:07:46 kube-calico-occm-1-14-no-volum-banz36g65egp-master-0.novalocal runc[2329]: E0404 11:07:46.814168       1 reconciler.go:293] attacherDetacher.AttachVolume failed to start for volume "html-volume" (UniqueName: "kubernetes.io/cinder/3eb1f62c-ab73-416e-b198-a159879dcc1b") from node "kube-calico-occm-1-14-no-volum-banz36g65egp-minion-0" : AttachVolume.NewAttacher failed for volume "html-volume" (UniqueName: "kubernetes.io/cinder/3eb1f62c-ab73-416e-b198-a159879dcc1b") from node "kube-calico-occm-1-14-no-volum-banz36g65egp-minion-0" : unable to create OpenStack cloud provider from default path : warnings:'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2019-04-05 09:29:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

this patch also break access to logs when we have fips.

The fip doesn't exist in the cert. For this feature to work properly, all ips of the node must be in the cert.

We are not ready for this patch. Let's revert and do the above changes first."}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2019-04-05 09:29:33.000000000', 'content': 'Created a revert of this change as I48b98b76fc4548290a7978521de5fb3d77a3a99a'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-04-05 09:33:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

What do you mean by break access to log? Which logs?'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-04-05 11:40:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Do you mean this:
```
[fedora@k8s-kew3j2665k3w-master-0 ~]$ kubectl log openstack-cloud-controller-manager-fwmhg -n kube-system
log is DEPRECATED and will be removed in a future version. Use logs instead.
Error from server: Get https://[fd6c:c6d0:b99c:0:f816:3eff:febb:66d5]:10250/containerLogs/kube-system/openstack-cloud-controller-manager-fwmhg/openstack-cloud-controller-manager: dial tcp [fd6c:c6d0:b99c:0:f816:3eff:febb:66d5]:10250: connect: connection refused
```
I am getting this error with or without the internal-network-name so this can't be related."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-04-05 15:48:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ah my default devstack network had both ipv4 and ipv6 subnet which was the reason behind why I couldn't access logs. I think the solution is to use different cloud-config files for openstack-cloud-controller-manager and kube-controller-manager since kube-controller-manager freaks out when it sees an option that is supported by occm but not in-tree openstack."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-04-05 15:59:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> this patch also break access to logs when we have fips.
 > 
 > The fip doesn't exist in the cert. For this feature to work
 > properly, all ips of the node must be in the cert.

Can you help me understand how to reproduce this? I can access all logs when I used diverged configs."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-30 08:01:20.000000000', 'message': 'Specify internal network to improve stability in a multi-NIC scenario.

When there is more than one NIC attached to an instance, openstack cloud
provider returns a random InternalIP back to the host resulting in instability
with API server which only talks to a default interface.

This patch incorporates the changes made in
https://github.com/kubernetes/cloud-provider-openstack/pull/444 which enables
OpenStack Cloud Controller Manager to respect the `internal-network-name` in
cloud-config file which ensures that InternalIP remains stable.

Story: 2005333
Task: 30271

Change-Id: I9e3ad459dd05753b53cb4ce75ee3aed649fef196
'}]
commit_message:
Specify internal network to improve stability in a multi-NIC scenario.

When there is more than one NIC attached to an instance, openstack cloud
provider returns a random InternalIP back to the host resulting in instability
with API server which only talks to a default interface.

This patch incorporates the changes made in
https://github.com/kubernetes/cloud-provider-openstack/pull/444 which enables
OpenStack Cloud Controller Manager to respect the `internal-network-name` in
cloud-config file which ensures that InternalIP remains stable.

Story: 2005333
Task: 30271

Change-Id: I9e3ad459dd05753b53cb4ce75ee3aed649fef196

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-04 03:00:05.000000000', 'message': 'Uncap jsonschema

We have jsonschema capped at a fairly old version. Other than some
specific releases, it looks like keeping it below 3.0 was added in
I943fd68b9fab3bce1764305a5058df5339470757 without really any explanation
why.

In order to update to a 3.x release we need to:
1. Remove the cap from global-requirements.txt (see Depends-On), leaving
   upper-constraints.txt at a 2.x release
2. Remove the cap from all consumers (this change)
3. Release a new version of consumers that are published to pypi
4. Update upper-constraints.txt with those new releases
5. Update jsonschema in upper-constraints.txt to a 3.X release
   (See: https://review.openstack.org/649789)
6. Test consumers with the change from 5.
7. [Optional] fix issues in consumers that arise from 6.
8. Merge the change from 5.

Change-Id: I229ab45375c1c5a06c283b1d0cde3c2d951e5dd8
Co-Authored-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/649669
'}]
commit_message:
Uncap jsonschema

We have jsonschema capped at a fairly old version. Other than some
specific releases, it looks like keeping it below 3.0 was added in
I943fd68b9fab3bce1764305a5058df5339470757 without really any explanation
why.

In order to update to a 3.x release we need to:
1. Remove the cap from global-requirements.txt (see Depends-On), leaving
   upper-constraints.txt at a 2.x release
2. Remove the cap from all consumers (this change)
3. Release a new version of consumers that are published to pypi
4. Update upper-constraints.txt with those new releases
5. Update jsonschema in upper-constraints.txt to a 3.X release
   (See: https://review.openstack.org/649789)
6. Test consumers with the change from 5.
7. [Optional] fix issues in consumers that arise from 6.
8. Merge the change from 5.

Change-Id: I229ab45375c1c5a06c283b1d0cde3c2d951e5dd8
Co-Authored-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/649669

commit_message:
Drop support for a templated catalog

This was only half-working anyway since we moved to keystone V3, so we
should just drop it. If someone wants to configure their deployment with
it, they can easily set up a wrapper for it.

Change-Id: Ifdf96502d18895e3b79dfa235fd102b42a0f4bc3

Build a deploy-guide

Seems that since we are a deployment project, we should produce a
deployment guide rather than an installation guide. Using
what OpenStack-Ansible did as a guide.

[{'created': '2019-04-03 13:58:56.000000000', 'message': 'Format generated MAC addresses using eui48.mac_unix_expanded

In Ml2Plugin.create_port_bulk, the MAC generated using netaddr.EUI
have the following format:
  "XX-XX-XX-XX-XX-XX"

In order to make them more compatible with other systems, the
following format is more appropiate:
  "00:01:23:45:67:ab"

eui48.mac_unix_expanded formater will add leading zeros if needed.

Change-Id: Ice382c0b4738a5a2576a3a4b151059715f106b40
Closes-Bug: #1822999
'}]
commit_message:
Format generated MAC addresses using eui48.mac_unix_expanded

In Ml2Plugin.create_port_bulk, the MAC generated using netaddr.EUI
have the following format:
  "XX-XX-XX-XX-XX-XX"

In order to make them more compatible with other systems, the
following format is more appropiate:
  "00:01:23:45:67:ab"

eui48.mac_unix_expanded formater will add leading zeros if needed.

Change-Id: Ice382c0b4738a5a2576a3a4b151059715f106b40
Closes-Bug: #1822999

[{'created': '2019-04-03 13:33:39.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure that bulk port dicts have unix-style MAC addresses

The bulk port code uses the Port OVO object, which encodes MAC address
as a netaddr.EUI object.  The default string representation for a
netaddr.EUI object is the standard IEEE EUI-48 format
("XX-XX-XX-XX-XX-XX") [1].  Having MAC addresses in that format breaks
the midonet gate, so revert to UNIX standard mac addresses
("xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx").

[1] https://netaddr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorial_02.html#formatting

Change-Id: I2d2727335c347accdeb39cbac5151722e8a3339c
Closes-Bug: #1822999

commit_message:
Ensure that bulk port dicts have unix-style MAC addresses

The bulk port code uses the Port OVO object, which encodes MAC address
as a netaddr.EUI object.  The default string representation for a
netaddr.EUI object is the standard IEEE EUI-48 format
("XX-XX-XX-XX-XX-XX") [1].  Having MAC addresses in that format breaks
the midonet gate, so revert to UNIX standard mac addresses
("xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx").

[1] https://netaddr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorial_02.html#formatting

Change-Id: I2d2727335c347accdeb39cbac5151722e8a3339c
Closes-Bug: #1822999

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-22 00:02:40.000000000', 'message': 'More accurate agent restart state transfer

Ovs-agent can be very time-consuming in handling a large number
of ports. At this point, the ovs-agent status report may have
exceeded the set timeout value. Some flows updating operations
will not be triggerred. This results in flows loss during agent
restart, especially for hosts to hosts of vxlan tunnel flow.

This fix will let the ovs-agent explicitly, in the first rpc loop,
indicate that the status is restarted. Then l2pop will be required
to update fdb entries.

Conflicts:
	neutron/plugins/ml2/rpc.py

commit_message:
More accurate agent restart state transfer

Ovs-agent can be very time-consuming in handling a large number
of ports. At this point, the ovs-agent status report may have
exceeded the set timeout value. Some flows updating operations
will not be triggerred. This results in flows loss during agent
restart, especially for hosts to hosts of vxlan tunnel flow.

This fix will let the ovs-agent explicitly, in the first rpc loop,
indicate that the status is restarted. Then l2pop will be required
to update fdb entries.

Conflicts:
	neutron/plugins/ml2/rpc.py

Closes-Bug: #1813703
Closes-Bug: #1813714
Closes-Bug: #1813715
Closes-Bug: #1794991
Closes-Bug: #1799178

Change-Id: I8edc2deb509216add1fb21e1893f1c17dda80961
(cherry picked from commit a5244d6d44d2b66de27dc77efa7830fa657260be)
(cherry picked from commit cc49ab550179bdc76d79f48be67886681cb43d4e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-29 00:09:35.000000000', 'message': 'Add topology_map option to manage scale and flavors

The --*-flavor and --*-scale cli options have been deprecated for some
time. In order to remove them, we need to be able to pass
Overcloud<rolename>Count and Overcloud<rolename>Flavor to the
deployment. This change adds a new configuration option which can be
used to manage these options in quickstart. In order to configure these
options as part of the deploy a user should specify the topology_map
with a dictionary using the rolename as a key with scale and flavor
underneath the flavor.

Example:

  topology_map:
    Controller:
      scale: 3
      flavor: controller
    Compute:
      scale: 1
      flavor: compute
    CephStorage:
      scale: 3
      flavor: ceph

NOTE: It is important that the rolenames in the key match the
capitalization of actual role.

Change-Id: Id2bc5692ebce3b2d937ca16665ef7af8390ded07

commit_message:
Add topology_map option to manage scale and flavors

The --*-flavor and --*-scale cli options have been deprecated for some
time. In order to remove them, we need to be able to pass
<rolename>Count and Overcloud<rolename>Flavor to the
deployment. This change adds a new configuration option which can be
used to manage these options in quickstart. In order to configure these
options as part of the deploy a user should specify the topology_map
with a dictionary using the rolename as a key with scale and flavor
underneath the flavor.

Example:

  topology_map:
    Controller:
      scale: 3
      flavor: controller
    Compute:
      scale: 1
      flavor: compute
    CephStorage:
      scale: 3
      flavor: ceph

NOTE: It is important that the rolenames in the key match the
capitalization of actual role.

Change-Id: Id2bc5692ebce3b2d937ca16665ef7af8390ded07

Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove dead code

Far as I can tell, this has no users outside of a unit test and can
therefore be removed.

Change-Id: I844959d2a6cf956cb59a78fddbec5301fb9fdc4b
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Debug check_python3_support_for_package_remote

We are hitting issues with parsing the python 3 classifier
from the pypi metadata json API response in rax-dfw for
some reason. One theory is that we are getting an empty
or partial result, so this patch adds debug logging if we
hit either case. It also fixes a logging statement associated
with the result of check_python3_support_for_package_remote
to use the package name rather than the package directory name
since we are checking pypi for the former.

Change-Id: I5a8003106a5a10a9e0d9d9d964f7a3858a765b8d
Related-Bug: #1820892

> The help text looks fine.
 > 
 > Should we maybe set the default value to '/dev/urandom'?
 > 
 > According to "https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsRng" if
 > no filename is specified (which seems to be the case by default
 > currently) then qemu will use "/dev/random" by default.

Yes, Nova can set default to /dev/urandom.  (Also, most other projects are overriding the QEMU default to /dev/urandom anyway; e.g. the libguestfs project: https://github.com/libguestfs/libguestfs/blob/master/lib/launch-direct.c#L592)

And QEMU upstream itself should default to /dev/urandom; I raised it on their upstream mailing list.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-06-25 12:09:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-06-25 13:10:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Since libvirt 1.3.4 any RNG device is accepted.  However, the
recommended source of entropy is `/dev/urandom` (as it doesn't have the
same limitations of `dev/random`; and doesn't block as easily).

Update the documention to reflect that.

Change-Id: Ia39402a045ffb1943463b5741655d84071613e8c

Since libvirt 1.3.4, any RNG device path (that returns random numbers
when read!) is accepted.  However, the recommended source of entropy is
`/dev/urandom` (it is non-blocking; and  doesn't have the same
limitations of `dev/random`, which is a legacy interface).

Update the documention to reflect that.

Change-Id: Ia39402a045ffb1943463b5741655d84071613e8c

returns random numbers when read!) is accepted.  However, the
recommended source of entropy is `/dev/urandom` (it is non-blocking; and

returns random numbers when read!) is accepted.  However, the
recommended source of entropy is `/dev/urandom` (it is non-blocking; and

Therefore, make `/dev/urandom` the default RNG for 'rng_dev_path' config

commit_message:
conf: libvirt: Make `/dev/urandom` the default for 'rng_dev_path'

Since libvirt 1.3.4, any RNG (Random Number Generator) device path (that
returns random numbers when read!) is accepted.  However, the
recommended source of entropy is `/dev/urandom` (it is non-blocking; and
doesn't have the same limitations of `dev/random`, which is a legacy
interface).

Therefore, make `/dev/urandom` the default RNG for 'rng_dev_path' config
attribute; adjust the relevant tests.  Also update the documention to
reflect this change.

Change-Id: Ia39402a045ffb1943463b5741655d84071613e8c
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
Reported-by: Daniel P. Berrangé <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Expand on a brief error message

In this case, the remote server did not supply any information
about the error.  Tell the user this so it doesn't look like
the SDK library is accidentally omitting anything.

Change-Id: I8f4757d2075c7cb4708df7b387f02beb2d4e671d

commit_message:
Install libmaas for stonith plugin

The libmaas stonith plugin uses libmaas which is supplied via
python3-libmaas. python3-libmaas is available from bionic onwards
so install it where possible.

Also, drive by fix to precreate /etc/pacemaker dir if needed to fix
trusty installs.

Closes-Bug: #1823300
Closes-Bug: #1823302

Change-Id: Ib14146f7f667f9c52e11d222f950efcb7cb47a7f
